verses.text: The words of King Lemuel—the oracle his mother taught him:
verses.comment: Proverbs 31 begins with the teachings of King Lemuel, attributed to his mother. While King Lemuel's identity is uncertain, tradition often associates this wisdom with Solomon. The passage highlights maternal instruction as an important source of wisdom, echoing other places where mothers are honored. See Prov. 1:8.

verses.text: "What, my son? What, son of my womb? What, son of my vows?
verses.comment: Lemuel's mother emphasizes the preciousness of her son, invoking her vows and the intimacy of motherhood—signalling deep spiritual responsibility in raising children.

verses.text: Do not give your strength to women, nor your ways to those who destroy kings.
verses.comment: Warning against sexual immorality and destructive relationships that have historically led to kings' downfall, as seen with Solomon. There’s spiritual meaning in safeguarding oneself for God-ordained purposes.

verses.text: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, not for kings to drink wine, or for rulers to crave strong drink,
verses.comment: Abstinence from intoxicants is wise for those in authority, reflecting the spiritual discipline expected of leaders.

verses.text: lest they drink and forget what has been decreed, and pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
verses.comment: This verse connects wisdom to justice; leaders must remain sober to defend the vulnerable, foreshadowing Christ, the just King and advocate for the afflicted (Ps. 72:12).

verses.text: Give strong drink to the one who is perishing, and wine to those with bitter hearts.
verses.comment: While rulers abstain, the suffering may find relief—echoes of compassion found throughout Scripture. This verse points subtly to sacramental imagery and spiritual comfort.

verses.text: Let him drink and forget his poverty, and remember his trouble no more.
verses.comment: Alleviation of despair for the suffering—symbolically, a foreshadowing of hope found in spiritual consolation.

verses.text: Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all who are forsaken.
verses.comment: A call for advocacy, echoing the prophetic imperative to speak for those without a voice. This motif continues in the ministry of Jesus (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: Open your mouth, judge righteously, defend the rights of the poor and needy.
verses.comment: Upholding justice, especially for society's vulnerable, echoes divine justice; spiritual leaders are expected to defend the oppressed.

verses.text: Who can find a woman of virtue? For her worth is far above jewels.
verses.comment: The virtuous woman is of priceless value. This sets up the famous description—a Christian ideal reflected in both literal marriage and as typological of the Church as bride.

verses.text: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will have no lack of gain.
verses.comment: Emphasizes fidelity and unity in marriage, reflecting deeper spiritual unity between Christ (the Bridegroom) and the Church.

verses.text: She brings him good, and not harm, all the days of her life.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and generosity characterize the ideal spouse, a model of Christian virtue.

verses.text: She seeks wool and flax, and works with willing hands.
verses.comment: Her diligence recalls the value of hard work—a virtue praised throughout wisdom literature and the New Testament (1 Thess. 4:11).

verses.text: She is like merchant ships, bringing in food from far away.
verses.comment: The wife’s resourcefulness and provision evokes themes of abundance, echoing God’s providence for His people.

verses.text: She rises while it is still night and provides food for her household, and portions for her servant girls.
verses.comment: Her self-sacrifice and care for others mirror spiritual nourishment, pointing to the Christian call to serve.

verses.text: She considers a field and buys it; from her earnings she plants a vineyard.
verses.comment: Her wise management and fruitful labor symbolize prudent stewardship—a theme echoed in the parables of Jesus (Matt. 25:14-30).

verses.text: She equips herself with strength and makes her arms strong.
verses.comment: Physical and spiritual strength go hand-in-hand; Christians are encouraged to be strong in faith and virtue (Eph. 6:10).

verses.text: She perceives that her merchandise is good; her lamp does not go out at night.
verses.comment: Constant vigilance and diligence—her lamp recalls spiritual watchfulness, like the wise virgins who kept oil for their lamps (Matt. 25:1-13).

verses.text: She puts her hands to the distaff, and her hands hold the spindle.
verses.comment: Her industriousness is a repeated theme here—hard work as a spiritual virtue.

verses.text: She opens her hand to the poor and extends her hands to the needy.
verses.comment: Generosity and compassion are keys to biblical spirituality—foreshadowing Christ’s call to care for ‘the least of these.’

verses.text: She is not afraid of snow for her household, for all of them are clothed in scarlet.
verses.comment: Meaning, she provides well, so her family is protected. Scarlet implies richness and preparedness, likened in spiritual symbolism to being covered and protected by grace.

verses.text: She makes coverings for herself; her clothing is fine linen and purple.
verses.comment: Purple and fine linen connote dignity and virtue, attributes often referenced for spiritual excellence and royal priesthood (1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: Her husband is respected at the city gates, where he takes his seat among the elders of the land.
verses.comment: Her virtue brings honor to her husband, associating communal and family well-being with personal holiness—an image reminiscent of the household as a ‘domestic church’.

verses.text: She makes linen garments and sells them, and supplies belts to the merchants.
verses.comment: Her productivity goes beyond her own home; industry and generosity intermingle—symbolic of distributive grace in the community.

verses.text: Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she smiles at the future.
verses.comment: Virtue as spiritual ‘clothing’ is a metaphor frequently used in Scripture (Isa. 61:10). Confidence in God’s provision allows joy regarding the future.

verses.text: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
verses.comment: Wisdom and kindness merge in her teaching—a hallmark of true spiritual leadership.

verses.text: She watches over the ways of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.
verses.comment: Constant vigilance and industriousness, opposed to idleness—a virtue reinforced elsewhere in wisdom literature and apostolic teaching (2 Thess. 3:10).

verses.text: Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband also praises her:
verses.comment: Being called blessed echoes the sanctity attached to motherhood and virtue, reminiscent spiritually of the praise given to Mary in Christian tradition. (See Christ fulfilling the praise of the righteous—Ps. 1:1).

verses.text: "Many women have done excellently, but you surpass them all."
verses.comment: Excellence in virtue is held in utmost esteem, foreshadowing the ‘fullness of grace’ praised in the New Testament (Luke 1:28).

verses.text: Charm is deceitful, and beauty is fleeting; but a woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.
verses.comment: True virtue is found in reverence for God, which surpasses outward appearance—spiritual beauty’s superiority over physical beauty is a constant biblical theme.

verses.text: Give her of the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her in the gates.
verses.comment: Final commendation to reward virtue. Her deeds ‘praise her in the gates’ exemplifies not only earthly honor but also the spiritual reward of the righteous, akin to the image of the saints being acknowledged before the Lord (Rev. 19:8).
